description.en: This course will be delivered in two parts. Part one will give an overview of the core concepts in regional security before proceeding to examine the particular trends that shape security in East Asia. This will include an overview of China's geopolitics and perceptions of world order; the evolution of Japan's security policy during and after the Cold War; tension in the Taiwan Straits; and the security situation along the Korean Peninsula. Part two will examine the security challenges in South-East Asia. This will centre around the sometimes turbluent politics of integration within the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN). Specific issues to be examined will include the security challenges arising from state weakness within certain South-East Asian states such as terrorism, civil war, and military involvement in politics; tensions surrounding proposed ASEAN democratization; ASEAN's integration process compared to other regional organizations; and ASEAN's place within the wider Asia-Pacific security order.
description.et: Ainekursus koosneb kahest osast. Esimene osa annab ülevaate piirkondliku julgeoleku põhilistest mõistetest ning seejärel uurib suundumusi, mis kujundavad julgeolekuolukorra Ida-Aasias. Antakse ülevaate Hiina geopoliitikast ja hiinlaste arusaamast maailmakorrast; Jaapani julgeolekupoliitika arengutest Külma Sõja ajal ja pärast seda; pingetest Taiwani väinas ja julgeolekuolukorrast Korea poolsaarel. Teine osa uurib julgeolekustamise probleeme Kagu-Aasias. Keskpunktiks on ASEAN-i turbluentne integratsioonipoliitika. Uuritakse julgeoleku väljakutseid teatud Kagu-Aasia riikide nõrkuste tulenevalt, nt terrorism, kodusõda ja sõjaline osalus; pinged pakutud ASEAN demokratiseerimise ümber; ASEANi integratsiooniprotsessi võrdlus teiste piirkondlike organisatsioonidega ja ASEANi koht laiemas Aasia-Vaikse ookeani julgeolekukorras.

objectives.en: This course aims to examine the main security challenges framing international relations around the Asia-Pacific basin. This course will be delivered in two parts. Part one will examine the impact of China's rise as an economic and political power on the regional security landscape in East Asia, as well as the evolving direction of Japan's security policy and the security situation along the Korean Peninsula. Part two will assess regional integration and security among the states of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN).
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on analüüsida peamisi julgeoleku väljakutseid Aasia-Vaikse ookeani regiooni rahvusvaheliste suhete kujundamisel. Aine koosneb kahest osast. Selle esimene osa uurib Hiina tõusu mõju majanduslikule ja poliitilisele võimule Ida-Aasia julgeoleku maastikul ning Jaapani julgeolekupoliitika ja Korea poolsaare julgeolekukorra arenemise suunad. Teise osa hindab piirkondliku integratsioonipoliitikat ja julgeolekut ASEAN riikides.

notes.et:
Recommended course to be passed before attending this course is International Relations.

This course will be based mostly on lectures. Each lecture and seminar will encourage an active learning environment integrating student questioning, discussions and debates. As assessments, students will be requested to submit one short policy paper and to participate in group work in order to attain the final grade.

Additional information can be requested from Prof Eiki Berg, eiki.berg@ut.ee.

description.et: Students must submit a reflection paper (not exceeding 4000 words) based on the group work and reflecting on the knowledge gained in the course to assess the future challenges likely to have an ongoing influence in shaping the Asia-Pacific region. Assessment is differentiated according to the criteria mentioned above.

grade_preconditions.et: A student is eligible to receive a final grade having submitted the policy paper, reflection paper, and while meeting the participation requirements (involvement to discussions during the class, commitment and participation in the group work).

grade_evaluation.et:
Policy paper is worth 60% of the final grade.
Reflection paper based on group work is worth 40% of the final grade.

Both papers should comply with the guidelines for writing and formatting papers (available at www.skytte.ut.ee) and respect academic ethics. No plagiarism is tolerated.

debt_elimination.et: To be agreed individually with the course instructor
